hints_html:
The chain rule works nicely here. So nicely you’ll want to use it twice.

Remember that

\[\begin{aligned} e^{g(x)} = e^{g(x)} \frac{d}{dx}g(x)\end{aligned}\]

Alternatively, taking logarithms and using implicit differentiation will work again.
hints_latex: The chain rule works nicely here. So nicely you'll want to use it twice.

Alternatively, taking logarithms and using implicit differentiation will
work again.
hints_raw:
The chain rule works nicely here. So nicely you'll want to use it twice.
Remember that
:<math>
e^{g(x)} = e^{g(x)} \frac{d}{dx}g(x)
</math>
Alternatively, taking logarithms and using implicit differentiation will work again.
question: 2 (a)
sols_html:
Applying the chain rule twice gives

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) &= e^{(\sin x)^{2}}\tfrac{d}{dx}(\sin x)^{2} \\ &= e^{(\sin x)^{2}}(2\sin x)(\cos x)\end{aligned}\]

Taking logarithms and differentiating gives

\[\begin{aligned} \ln(f(x)) &= (\sin x)^{2} \\ \frac{f'(x)}{f(x)} &= 2\sin x\cos x \\ f'(x) &= 2f(x)\sin x\cos x \\ f'(x) &= 2e^{(\sin x)^{2}}\sin x\cos x \end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
Taking logarithms and differentiating gives

\begin{align*}
\ln(f(x)) &= (\sin x)^{2} \\
\frac{f'(x)}{f(x)} &= 2\sin x\cos x \\
f'(x) &= 2f(x)\sin x\cos x \\
f'(x) &= 2e^{(\sin x)^{2}}\sin x\cos x 
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
Applying the chain rule twice gives

<math> 
\begin{align}
f'(x) &= e^{(\sin x)^{2}}\tfrac{d}{dx}(\sin x)^{2} \\
&= e^{(\sin x)^{2}}(2\sin x)(\cos x)
\end{align}
</math>
Taking logarithms and differentiating gives

<math>
\begin{align}
\ln(f(x)) &= (\sin x)^{2} \\
\frac{f'(x)}{f(x)} &= 2\sin x\cos x \\
f'(x) &= 2f(x)\sin x\cos x \\
f'(x) &= 2e^{(\sin x)^{2}}\sin x\cos x 
\end{align}
</math>
